Award.AwardTitle: SNM: Inverse Design of Nanostructured Heterogeneous Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Scalable NanoManufacturing (SNM) grant provides funding for the development of a computational platform that will enable the synthesis of heterogeneous hierarchical nanomaterials in a prescribed and efficient manner. Such materials will be formed using block copolymer self-assembly on graphoepitaxial templates, a process known as templated self-assembly. The developed numerical tool will solve the inverse problem for the self-assembly process in which the input is the final nanoscale pattern (the target), and the output is the optimal template configuration that will yield such pattern given a set of constraints. The developed inverse self-assembly algorithm will be implemented in advanced parallel computational architectures such as graphic processing units. The algorithm will be tested in three different cases: periodic patterns with non-trivial symmetries, precise arrangement of nanoparticles in block copolymer matrices, and the interconnection of patterns with different symmetries. Experiments for each of the aforementioned cases will be performed to validate the computational results.

If successful, this research will lead to novel algorithms in solving the inverse self-assembly problem that in turn will lead to advances in the manufacturing of heterogeneous nanoscale materials. The primary goal of this project is to develop a toolkit that will determine the optimal templates for a given target pattern. Solving such problem on the computer in a directed and optimal fashion will reduce the costs and time to empirically construct the templates used in templated self-assembly. This has the potential to reduce the overall costs of nanomanufacturing by accelerating the processes and increasing the fidelity of the patterns for lithographic applications such as those needed in the semiconductor industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

SNM: Inverse Design of Nanostructured Heterogeneous Materials

PI: Alfredo Alexander-Katz1, co-PIs: Karl K.Berggren2, Bradley D. Olsen3, and Caroline A. Ross1 Departments of 1Materials Science and Engineering, 2Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, and 3Chemical Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Manufacturing heterogeneous nanostructured materials efficiently on a large scale is one of the biggest challenges in realizing the next revolution in manufacturing. Current methods for creating such materials are expensive and inefficient, and thus not scalable. Self-assembly, on the other hand, has the potential to overcome these limitations. This project focused on guiding the behavior of films of block copolymers, which spontaneously self-assemble into periodic structures with feature sizes of a few nm and above. The block copolymer assembly was guided by pre-patterning the substrate, and hierarchical structures were built up from multiple layers of block copolymers. The project included a close collaboration between experimental and theoretical approaches.

One of the highlights of the work was the formation of mesh-like structures with excellent order, which provides a simple way to create grid patterns useful in microelectronic device fabrication. The hierarchical meshes also provide a surface with super-hydrophobic properties, offering a convenient method for making water-repelling surfaces. Another key finding was a computational solution to the problem of how to design patterns on a substrate that will guide the self-assembly to make specific structures, for example features needed in manufacturing of integrated circuits. This allows a chip designer to determine how to efficiently produce dense, sub-10-nm features for making e.g. transistors or interconnects. The project also developed methods for transferring block copolymer patterns into functional materials such as metals or oxides, and how to incorporate nanoparticles with block copolymers.

The methods developed in this project can be used at multiple length scales, and facilitate the overall goal of designing heterogeneous nanostructured materials in a scalable fashion. This work demonstrates the creation of assemblies arranged from the nanoscale to the macroscale using simple templates, overcoming barriers to the deployment of block copolymer self-assembly as a standard nanomanufacturing process.

Nanomanufacturing represents the future in manufacturing and thus it will have broad impacts on society ranging from economic to educational. This proposal addressed both technological and educational nanomanufacturing innovations. On the technological side a platform for the design of de novo materials with prescribed properties was developed with wide ranging applications. The educational developments include offering worldwide education on the free edX platform, and multimedia demonstrations and hands-on experiences for the public at the NanoObservatory during the Cambridge Science Festival.

 


Last Modified: 10/02/2017
Modified by: Alfredo Alexander-Katz
